utterances: And I have to say, what really makes them cheesy, honestly, in that timeless way, is the hair, the makeup and the outfits.

An email from St. Louis, Missouri.
I attended the 1998 prom at Windsor High School at Imperial, Missouri, near St. Louis.
Since ""Titanic,"" the movie, was so popular around that time, that was the prom theme.
It was complete with an ice sculpture of the ill-fated ship.
Our prom song was, of course, ""My Heart Will Go On"" by Celine Dion.
A lot of people on our staff had A Night to Remember; of course that was the name of the other Titanic movie.
And all of their proms - they find the iceberg pretty early in the show.
I love that.
As long as that's not the, you know, what actually happens to your evening, that's lovely.
You know, let me throw in another tip for parents, if I could.
Go ahead.
One last one.
Okay, limos.
Please, parents, speak to the limo company and the limo driver.
A lot of limo companies actually have pretty strict no alcohol policy.
And I have watched limo drivers take evening bags, backpacks, everything else, off of kids and put them in the trunk during the ride.
And I actually think that's a pretty good idea.
Amy, as usual, thanks very much and good luck on prom night.

Joaquin Guzman, El Chapo, is on his way to prison for life.
A federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday sentenced the head of Mexico's Sinaloa drug cartel to life in prison without possibility of parole.
The sentence also includes a multibillion-dollar financial penalty.
Vice News senior reporter Keegan Hamilton has been following this trial since the beginning.
He is host of the Vice podcast ""Chapo: Kingpin On Trial,"" and he's in our studios here in New York.
Good morning.
Good morning.
What was it like to be in the courtroom yesterday?
It was a moment of drama, and somewhat unexpected drama.
I mean, the sentence was mandatory under the law that he was going to get life.
But what happened was Chapo spoke at length for the first time.
He hadn't testified in his defense before.
He spoke a few words to the judge - good morning, thank you - during the course of the trial, but this was the first time that he's been really able to speak his mind.

And so he gave about a 10-minute statement that he prepared, talking about how the conditions of his confinement in New York in solitary confinement were torture, talking about how he thought his conviction was unjust because the court didn't investigate reports of juror misconduct.
OK.
Did he acknowledge any of his crimes?
He really showed virtually no remorse whatsoever.
One of his victims, a former cartel member who he allegedly tried to have kidnapped and killed, spoke.

And as she was describing this moment where she was being abducted, he was turned and was blowing kisses at his wife in the gallery, so you could really see that it wasn't having too much of an effect on him.
Well, I also want to ask because federal prosecutors said he himself tortured people in extraordinary ways, and now he says his confinement is torture.
What about his confinement, according to El Chapo, anyway, is torture?
I mean, he is in, perhaps, the most extreme form of solitary confinement you could have in the United States.
He has very minimal human contact, no outdoor exercise.
We talked about how, you know, the air in his cell is giving him migraines and hurting his throat.
He has to - you make earplugs out of toilet paper in order to sleep.
And now he's going, likely, to this supermax prison in Colorado, which is also a pretty extreme form of solitary confinement.
Meaning that he will have very little human contact from now until whenever he dies.
Exactly right.
He will be at that prison likely until the day he's gone.
You know, this may be hard to look into the man's mind, but sometimes, you hear about a criminal or a dictator or an authoritarian who anticipates, someday, I'm going to come to a terrible end.
Do you think that he knew someday he would face an end like this?
I mean, I hate to read the guy's mind, but it's - everything that I've come to understand about him is that he thought he could keep getting away with it.
I mean, this is a guy who was - he'd escaped twice from prison in Mexico and was reportedly planning another escape before he was extradited.
So, you know, maybe yesterday was the moment he realized that there was no getting out; he was going to spend the rest of his life in a U.S.
prison.
But who knows?
Perhaps only he knows.
I wonder if he is also bothered by losing the $12 billion.
That's the penalty - right?
- $12 billion.
Well, prosecutors are trying to find $12.6 billion, but so far, they've come up empty.
And there's - that value is calculated by the total street value of all the drugs that he shipped to the U.S.
over 30 years, so it's not the actual cash assets he has.
He's surely spent some of that over time.
Certainly.
And whatever is left somebody else out there in the Sinaloa cartel has?
I mean, perhaps.
I mean, his sons and his brother have taken over the family business, so assume they have some money, but they're not going to be providing that to the feds anytime soon.
Mr.
Hamilton, thanks so much.
Appreciate it.
That's Vice News senior reporter Keegan Hamilton this morning.

Later in the program, exit interviews with Senator Joseph Lieberman and Congressman Ron Paul as they leave Congress after many years.

After they rejected President Obama's opening offer, Republicans issued a proposal of their own yesterday, which was promptly dismissed by the White House.
One group that's already worked out a series of compromises to come up with a comprehensive proposal is a nonpartisan group called Fix the Debt.
It emerged from the Simpson-Bowles Commission.
Its ideas include higher taxes on the wealthy and tax reform, plus changes to Social Security and Medicare.

Former Republican Senator Pete Domenici serves on the steering committee of Fix the Debt, co-chairs the Debt Reduction Task Force at the Bipartisan Policy Center, and he joins us now by phone from his office in Washington, D.C., and it's good of you to be with us today.
Thank you very much, Neal.

We've got a lot of us around, and we're trying to find our place in this thing, and it looks like the White House and the Republicans do have a way to get information in.
